Comment: Let’s stop feeding the narcissistic machine. Every time we use the T-word, we boost the brand of someone who wants us to obsess over him good or bad. Instead, let’s starve the algorithm. Rename him, deflate him, mock him, or better yet: erase his cultural dominance by refusing to say his name at all. Call him  DRUMPF, the Not-So-Great Pumpkin, Donnie Two-Scoops, Agent Orange, the Fauxphet, Cheeto Caesar, the Bronze Calf, Baron of Bankruptcy, or just The Former Guy. The less we use his real name, the less power he holds let mockery do the talking, and history do the forgetting.

Comment: This was my takeaway from 2024, and why I’m so quick to point out that a vote doesn’t communicate LEVEL of support.  It’s also completely changed my mind on a (up to this point) lifelong belief that compulsory voting would be a good idea.  Nah, we had pretty solid turnout, but it felt like a solid third of the people voting had no actual opinion, or knew nothing about the candidates and were just flipping a coin.  If you looked and Donald Trump and ANY other candidate and were “undecided”, yeah, maybe stay home.  You don’t pay enough attention to make an informed decision

Comment: Agreed. After watching republicans lose the popular vote in the vast majority of recent presidential elections, I was under the misapprehension that most non/infrequent voters were democratic diamonds in the rough. That was wrong.   I also question whether increasing voter turnout for its own sake is something democrats should continue focusing on. I heard that democratic canvassers in Arizona actually drove up republican voter turnout.   I know there are asymmetries in the coalitions, but republicans seem to do better with less. They are focused on who their supporters are and deliver (if selectively and otherwise only rhetorically).   Democratic policy is largely shaped by special interest groups and donors, many of whom are at odds with each other and out of touch with mainstream views and the sensibilities of the general public. It would be interesting if the party could trade expanding the tent to desperately prop up an electorally fragile coalition for changing its values so that it naturally appeals to more Americans, but given party leadership I don’t see that happening any time soon.
Author: fellow-fellow

They don't see themselves on the same level as "the left" ...they view "the left" as lower, very much like a racist sees other races as inherently lower.
